The URL page was created to illustrate this bug, it's about thirty lines of html most devoted to a select element. Although all options of the select element will fit in the browser window, even on my mini-screened netbook, Firefox includes a scroll bar. I have tested this on three different Linux versions 3.5.1, 3.5.9, 3.6.1 and all behave the same.


Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.Select form element with about 22 options
2.The bottom options will always be hidden and require scrolling.

Actual Results:  
Menus get scroll bars even though they would fit on screen.

Expected Results:  
Menus get scroll bars only when they would otherwise not fit on screen.
comments.author: mozilla@eli.users.panix.com

comments.raw_text: This is presumably intentional behaviour to stop excessively long listboxes. ie: Where do you draw the line? 20 items? 50 items? If you made the limit purely based on what could fit on the screen, then the listboxes could get quite unwieldy on certain pages, if the resolution was high.

comments.text:
> Where do you draw the line? 20 items? 50 items? 

kMaxDropDownRows is set to 20 in nsListControlFrame, quite on purpose (with some comments about this being compatible with older browsers, etc).

comments.text:
I cope just fine with large drop downs implemented in Javascript, why should I not have equivalent functionality using basic HTML? I'd say there should not be a fixed limit, but a limit based on line height and percent of window size.

Already if I zoom the fonts way up, the drop down in my example page will show only ten items. But if I zoom it way down, I don't get an increase in items shown. Drop the hard limit and only use the percentage limit.
comments.creator: mozilla@eli.users.panix.com
